A group of students is asked to experimentally determine the spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> of a spring using a linear graph. The students are provided with a block of known mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> that can move along a horizontal track with negligible friction. The right end of the track is curved. The end of the curved section of track is vertical, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. In addition to the block and track, the students are only allowed to use a meterstick. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine an experimental value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> using a linear graph. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be used to produce a linear graph, and how that graph could be analyzed to determine an experimental value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.

In a later experiment, the students are asked to determine an experimental value for the mass <math alttext="m sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></math> of a glider. The glider has length <math alttext="l equals 0.15 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>ℓ</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.15</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> and is initially at rest on a horizontal air track, which allows the glider to move along the track with negligible friction. A string is attached between the glider and a spring with a spring constant of <math alttext="k sub s equals 25 newtons per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>s</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.The glider is pulled to displace the spring an amount <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> from equilibrium and then released. The glider reaches its maximum speed before passing through the photogate. Indicate two quantities that could be graphed to produce a linear graph that could be used to determine <math alttext="m sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></math>. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.Vertical axis:__________ Horizontal axis:__________

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) that can be used to determine <math alttext="m sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></math>. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw a best-fit line that best represents the data.

(d) Using the best-fit line that you drew in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> in part (c)(iii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="m sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></msub></math>.
